channel.title: The New Yorker — Reporting
channel.description: Latest reporting from The New Yorker

item.title: Peter Navarro, Trump’s Ultimate Yes-Man
item.description: The tariff cheerleader established the template of sycophancy for Trump Administration officials.

item.title: Why Millennials Love Prenups
item.description: Long the province of the ultra-wealthy, prenuptial agreements are being embraced by young people—including many who don’t have all that much to divvy up.

item.title: Dyslexia and the Reading Wars
item.description: Proven methods for teaching the readers who struggle most have been known for decades. Why do we often fail to use them?

item.title: How Willie Nelson Sees America
item.description: On the road with the musician, his band, and his family.

item.title: A Mexican Couple in California Plans to Self-Deport—and Leave Their Kids Behind
item.description: Can undocumented parents eludeICEcapture for one more year, until their youngest turns eighteen?

item.title: The Making of the First American Pope
item.description: Will Pope Leo XIV follow the progressive example of his predecessor or chart a more moderate course? His work in Chicago and Peru may shed light on his approach.

item.title: Can We Save Wine from Wildfires?
item.description: The industry has lost billions of dollars, largely because smoke makes the drink taste like licking an ashtray. Now a team of scientists is chasing a solution.

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene’s Big Breakup
item.description: The congresswoman split with the President over the Epstein files, then she quit. Where will she go from here?

item.title: Denmark Is Sick of Being Bullied by Trump
item.description: The U.S., once Denmark’s closest ally, is threatening to steal Greenland and attacking the country’s wind-power industry. Is this a permanent breakup?

item.title: Patrick Radden Keefe on Truman Capote’s “In Cold Blood”
item.description: Capote’s journalistic transgressions were serious, but there is no denying the awesome influence of his work.
